text: 750 ml bottle. Clear, copper-red body with a small off-white head. Aroma has a lot of caramel malt, brown sugar and just a faint hint of Brett. Flavor is sweet malt, sweet caramel, some dry fruit and very little Brett/funk. Full bodied and aftertaste with sweet caramel malt. Way to sweet and not very interesting.

Bottle shared during the RBScSG2015. Pours tiny hazy golden with a small offwhite head that quickly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is slightly malty, slightly funky and slightly sugary with caramel, toffee, lemon juice, hay, leather, cheese, barnyard, horse blanket and lemon zest. Taste is sweet, tiny sour and funky. Mouthfeel is round, tiny tart and light to medium bodied. Finish is sweet and tiny sour with caramel, toffee, brown sugar, lemon juice, hay, leather, barnyard, horse blanket, cardboard and lemon zest. Old, cardboardy and unpleasantly sweet. Pass!

They say Faro pairs perfectly with Sci Fi so while watch g a film popped open this bottle from Ippopotamo36. Dull brown pour nose of apple skin and brown sugar. Tastes of apples, white wine, wood, some brown sugar, vinegar, and caramel. Not overly sweet which is much appreciated for bottle this size when enjoying by yourself. Actually quite pleasant sipper. Thanks a ton Alberto!
Bottle, new batch, 25cl. Medium carbonation. Sweet nose of caramel, brown sugar. Also some funkiness. Citrus and lemon. Light bitter finish. Ok.
Bottle @ Grand Tasting, RBSCSG 2015. Amber with a tiny off white head. Fruity and acidic tones. Fryuit, malt and sour. Medium body with a long bitter / sour finish.

Bottle at Grand Tasting, RBSCSG 2015 cons 2015-07-11 Göteborg
Yes, my Faro #5....
AR: caramel, yeasty, honey
AP: amber clear, wee white head
F: sweet candy or candis, footsweet, dry, bread syrup
Sample at RBScSG.Hazy amber with off white head. Smell is sour, funky with spices and sugar. Taste is sour with brown sugar, candisugar and berries. Semi sweet with low carbonation.

Sampled at RBScSG-15 Thx ekstedt
Hazy amber with a bubbly head. 
Spicy aroma. 
Stale and flat. 
A bit sourish with brown sugar.
Bottle. Shared at Dangerous Bottle Share 8.0. Bronze pour with a decent off white head. Nose is sweet, cheesy, brown sugar. Taste is light bitter, funky, cheesy and sweet.

Shared at Dangerous Bottleshare #8. Thanks to Bursprak for this! Pours light hazy dark orange with a thick white head. Aromas of green apples, vinegar, hay, brett, sugar, citrus, cheese. Taste is green apples, sweet sugary notes, hay, cheese, citrus.

Bottle shared @ dangerous bottleshare #8 . Pours hazy amber with a bright tan head. Aroma is pretty rural with some sour apples, funky brett, weak vinegar, horse blanket and some more sugary and malty notes as well. The taste has some weak cheese, weak sugar, sour apples, sweeter caramel notes, ginger, vinegar and dry wood. Faro has never been my style but this was drinkable indeed!

Bottle at Dangerous Bottleshares #8, thanks to Bursprak. Pours a dark amber with a medium sized, white head. Aroma is pretty weak with some sweet, white grapes, slight vinegar, slight cheese. Taste is pretty sweet with some funky and more tart notes. Very easy drinking lambic, and the balance is actually pretty good!

Bottle shared. Pours slight hazy Amber brown with a small off white head. Aroma of funk, dusty notes, tart fruits and barnyard. Flavour is moderate sweet and light acidic. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Sample courtesy of Kermis at my 20th anniversary in NL party.
Thin creamy white head. hazy golden pour. Balanced sweetness and sourness. Not bad at all.

A kind of faro, undoubtedly blended with their Ulrich Lager. Creamy, sticky, snow white head, colour pure amber, warm glow. Sweaty lambic aroma, sherry, hay, fennle seed, strawberry, mango, white pepper, pale malts, cinnamon. Bit sugary sweetness in onset, aromatic herbs (star aniseed?), smooth and somewhat thin mouthfeel, light acidity, subtle lambic character, clearly diluted by a normal beer, light bitterness in the end. A curiosity and not much more than a variation on Girardin Faro, not well-suited for the diehard fans of authentic lambics, but still lambic-like enough to be enjoyable.
Hazy light amber, sweet front, caramel, touch herbal, and thats a lot of the taste. Bland, just a touch of faro character, but fruity and almost sodalike.

750mL bottle, sent from mista (thanks a lot, Geoff), pours a hazy amber with a small off-white head. Nose brings out funk, light sugar, a little vinegar and more funk. Flavour certainly is interesting, with unusual notes, with sugar, an herbal quality, pickled vegetables, and some very subtle funk. The sweetness is artificial tasting -- must be the sucralose thats used here. Not the most elegant faro, but its quite intriguing in its uniqueness.

Bottle. Clear copper pour with thin bubbly white head. Aroma is malty, nice funk, more than I would have expected from such a blend, lambic-y notes. Taste is sweet, light wet hay, very mild funk, caramel, interesting. Palate is sweet, med bodied with good carbonation. Not half as bad as I thought quite drinkable faro.

Bottle (750 ml). Hazy copper with a small ring of off-white foam and little lacing. Aroma is funkier than expected, but theres also the usual brown sugar along wooden notes, light minty presence and hints of fruits. Taste is slightly funky and slightly sweet with brown sugar, wood, light fruits and a nice minty touch. Medium body. Low/moderate carbonation. Not bad at all for a Faro. Less sweet and a little funkier than most of the other Faro that I have tried. Drinkable for the style and somewhat tasty too.

75cl bottle, bottled 2009.   Amber-brown in the glass. The nose is fruity-woody with hints of dark sourness. The beer starts intense-concentrated. Woody, Faro-sweetish. Tart. A bit dusty. The mainpart is dusty, smooth Faro-typical sweetish, malty. The woody sourness is not that intense, but present. The aftertaste is long, sweetish-dusty with wood and caramel. Not really highly drinkable. Therefore too dusty, probably too old.  Interesting brew. --> 10/11/9/10

750mL thanks to t0rin0. Clear tea amber pour, wispy foam. Nose is black peppercorn, sharp steak au poivre, bizarre Faro sweet tea, spicy potpourri orange, and strange funk. Taste is sweet southern iced tea up front, sugary. Palate is not bright, more of a musty, sticky past its prime. Overall, I cannot say this is good in any way.

Corked 0.75l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. A lovely warm amber orange colored thing this with a small islandy and lacing off-white head. It has a fruity bretty aroma with peaches, red berries and a little wood hint. Yeah, Smells really nice! Oh, its sweeter than I thought. Soft and really thin on the mouthfeel and also soft prickling on the carbonation. Red Berry sweet with thin raspberry lemonade. Surprisingly sweet, and not very interesting or even good to be honest. Smells quite nice but Im a bit disappointed in this hybrid. 23.10.2013

Sampled @ RBBSG II. Courtesy of BelgBeerGeek. Pours a bright clear copper color with a light tan ring for carbonation. The smell is tart fruit while the taste is a nice balance between sweet and sour with cherry, a little saccharine then a dry ending. Bright carbonation and light+ body.
Pours copper with white head. Aroma is sour, fruity and somewhat acidic. Flavour is earthly, light to medium bitter and medium sour.

Appearance: Hazy deep golden color with a small white head.Aroma: Sweet fruity and mild sour.Palate: Medium body and slightly sweet. Soft carbonation. Oily texture.Taste: Fruity and a mild acidic sourness.Overall impression: An ok Faro. But I am not running to buy another one.Personal stats: Bottle @ Geokkjer

Bottle 750ml @ Geokkjer
Pours slightæy hazy copper with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of funk, tart and some fruits. Taste is medium sweet and light sour with and dry, sweet and fruity finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 23.10.2013, 0,75l bottle sampled @ BBGTC tasting:
Small creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is sweet sour-ish, sugar, sorrel, hints of sour fruits. Taste is slightly sweet, sugar, grass, oak, sorrel. Pretty boring.
Light amber colored with a small head. Aroma is light fruity with light malts. Taste is somewhat sweet with mellow fruit. Light and somewhat watery.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Hazy deep orange body, small white head. Nose is pale malts, sour lactic tones, hints of red fruits and straw. Taste is mild pale malts, faint sour tones, sweet grains and straw. Light body and medium carbonation. A bit watery. Not a very good one.
Bottle. Clear amber beer with a lacy big offwhite head. Sourish, fruity aroma with rubber notes. Sweet, a bit sourish flavour with berry notes.

75cl bottle picked up at the Beer Temple in Brussels. It pours clear pale copper with a thin off white head. The mild aroma offers up some cherry juice cut by water, some sugary sweetness, a bit of red apple and then lighter notes of yeasty funk and slight tartness. The taste is fairly light on the palate and fruity with snippets of spicy yeast and slight tartness and funk interceding among cherry and ripe red apple notes. Pretty nice. It seems to leave a slight film sort of sensation behind on the palate.

had this one for a while.. opening it alone since nobody seems to care about this ( while i find it rather intresting) yet a bit afraid, faro and pils blended, best before the end of 2011. were almost 2013. for faro, that dhould be alright , for pils... also i realy , realy did not like the faro girardin i drank last week... so here it goes, all or nothing? 

pours clear copper, very small foam ( more like a layer on the beer than a foam) and a weakened faro-smell. taste is not TOO bad. i still can taste the bad aspects of the firardin faro ( the harshness drinkability, sourness in a bad way.. if anyone understands dutch  -- een wrange smaak-- (however you say that in english) but the good sides of it come more forward. like in any faro so far i have a very specific , aplle-all-over taste ( that seems to be onley with me, while its so straight that.. weird) that i like and that comes better to the front in this one. 
also is more drinkable.

i would say this is a better version of their faro ( becouse its weeker in taste) but it doesnt get close to the other i drank ( lindemans and straffe winter).. im gonna try to finish a whole bottle of this, wish me luck !
Bottled, thx rlgk. Pours copper with a small white head. Smells and tastes rubber, sour, pepper, abit wood and suger.

75 cl bottle. Clear golden beer with a quite nice offwhite head. Rubber aroma, tart, sour, vinegar notes, sweetish, acidic, juniper berries, woody notes. Sweet rubber flavor, caramel, stable, barnyard, sugary, saccharin, juniper berries, vinegar, dandelions, perfume notes. Quite sweet finish with rubber and leather notes, barnyard, vinegar and some dandelions.

(75 cl bottle, bought in 2009, opened 11/2012)  Chestnut-coloured and hazy with a creamy beige head. Smells of sherry, with fruity and peppery notes. Aroma of cherries, apples, caramel and madeira wine as well. Hardly any bitterness, but some some acidity and sweetness. Moderate and tolerable sweetness at first, that becomes stronger with time and is  an important part of the aftertaste. I guess thats what the sucralose does, that can be found on the list of ingredients. I would have preferred a tart and drier finish, but then it probably would not pass as a Faro. I was still pleasantly surprised by this beer, that to me tastes like a mixture of oud bruin and lambic. I dont get the pilsener part, though - is that really in the mix? Anyway: different and interesting.

Bottle (thanks to hannont for sharing)...  Poured a cloudy, golden, burnt orange with zero head.  Nose had cedar, wood-like incense, and dominant yeast.  Some acidity, funk, and tartness that meshed with spices and light fruits, along with wood (especially what came off like cedar).  I could see this may be awkward and astringent to others.  But I enjoyed it quite a bit.

Bottle shared by "hannont".  Colour...semi hazy gold with no head. Nose...smells like a humidor with a lean towards cedar though the tobacco is there as well. Palate...lightly tart and sweet up front with an Aspartame like aftertaste then a brief shot of fruit before the flavour disappears.
Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, adicid notes and light leather. Flavour is sweet caramel, scidic notes, fruity. Dry aftertaste.

Pours a clear and copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, acidic and some tart. The flavor follows the nose with additional sweetness. The palate is dry with sweetness and some acidity. Overall a good beer. [Rating #3500]

At recent RBBSG my bottle  
Head: small white, foamy 
Colour: dark redish amber 
Smell: malts, some sour, somewhat irony and sweet 
Taste: somewhat similar to the aroma , typical Faro with typical Pilsner in the flavour ( cause this is a Lambic/Pilsner blend ... )

Dark amber colour, white head. Aroma of brown sugar, quite tart, caramel and overripe fruit. Quite sweet, light sour flavour, quite some caramel. Sweet finish.
(From 75cL bottle @ RBBSG II, Wilrijk. Courtesy of BelgBeerGeek. Thanks Vincent!)

thx. to Vincent / Belgbeergeek // 75 cl. bottle sampled @ RBBSG 2012 // copper / amber coloured with not much of a head // aroma / lambic dominates over the sugar. Girardin lambic clearly noticeable, lemon tartness blended with a definetly present but not overpowering candy sugar // taste is sour lemon with some mellow malt=like elements, light barnyard funk, touch of spices, hint wood and that bitterness that some lambics can have with a clear layer of partially eaten candy sugar running through it, almost musty // mellow, softer carb. neat in a style that I have mixed feelings about even if I like it

75cl Bottle@ RBBSG, courtesy of BelgBeerGeek. Amber coloured beer with a small white head and no carbonation. Light sour, short grainy hinted aroma. Medium to full palate, smouth and little sweet. Finish is sweet fruity. Rather sweet with a light grainy sour herby sweet balanced hint to it. Not bad.

Bottle from Willems. I drank this in memory of Jan Girardin and all the wonderful beers I have had from Girardin the past few years. Hazy orange with a big and lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dark sugar, wood and pepper. Flavor is quite sweet and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. 160812

Bottle sample @ 2nd RBBSG, August 11th 2012. Courtesy of BelgBeerGeek.
Ambrée, col fin blanc.
Arôme garde ce profile lambic avec ce bouquet sucre brun, le tout ayant une pointe plus avancée de houblons et herbes.
Palais reste dans le style faro, légère, sucré sur qcq notes aigres / lambic. Note pomme caramel avec au fini une pointe dépices et daromates.

19/VI/2012 - 75 cl bottle from Geers or De Hopduvel (not sure) @ Johns place - BB: ? no indication on cork (2012-639) 
Clear amber to red orange beer, nice irregular white head, unstable, little adhesive. Aroma: pretty fruity, bit metallic, lime juice, ripe pears and plums. MF: soft carbon, light to medium body. Taste: sweet start, sugary, some caramel, ripe cherries, bit sour, lemony. Aftertaste: sourish, caramel, some hop bitterness, lemony. Not bad. Would have never guessed its a faro. Is it?

Bottle at the Hill Farmstead second anniversary party courtesy of someone, but I cant remember who.  So whomever you were, thanks.  Pours an amber ruby with a medium sized white head.  Musk, acid and funk on the nose.  Medium bodied, very lactic, but rather soft.  Funky, musk, lots of sweet toast on the finish.

bottle.    musty old fruit, a touch vegetal, some light leather and faint sour cherry sourness.    not bad, but not particularly great either.  doughy malt backing with a touch of raw sugar.  no trace of girardin black-esque lambic to be found.   okay.

Pours a hazy copper with a thin foamy white head that quickly dissipates.  Smells of funk, some earthy hints, some fruity elements, some residual sugary splashes.  Tastes acidic and semi sweet with some moderate fruity undertones and a funky finish.  Not bad.

75cl green bottle. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a minimal off-white head. Foam dissipates quickly. Aroma is funk and caramel, with spices and flowers. Taste is miedium acidic, with sour and funk. Notes of burnt suger and slight booze. Some wood and a hint of vinegar as well. When warmed up, this beer almost recalls a flemish red, like a mix o lambic with a 30% of flemish red. Thin in body and little carbonation. Not bad, definitely interesting.

Bottle.  Clear amber color, large fluffy white head with good retention and solid lacing.  Aroma of subtle earthy caramel.  Taste starts sweet cotton candy then bitter toast and straw.  Light body.  Interesting.

In short: A slightly sweet acidic lambic with an unexpected red-fruits flavor.  Very original
How: Bottle 750ml.  Exact age unknown
The look: Slightly cloudy light-copper body topped by a small beige head
In long: Nose is musty, rustic, a bit funky and with a good amount of unexpected red fruits.  This is supposed to be a faro (according to ratebeer current style) so I was really surprised by the color and aromas.  Taste has a little sweetness but it is a lot less sweet than what I expect from a faro.  The sweetness felt like red fruits sweetness.  In a blind tasting I would have sworn this was a fruit-lambic with an unusual fruit (some exotic red fruit of some kind).  The beer ends with a sharp acidic tartness that is a bit reminiscent of raspberry pits.  Acidity level is pretty much the same as a regular fruit Lambic but there is no almost no sourness.  This was a strange beast for sure and drinking a full bottle was actually quite easy (compared to most lambics).  I think this beer is both underrated and probably wrongly classified as a Faro (which could explain the underrated part).  Thats my opinion and unless someone tells me the things I write in my ratings dont make any sense I will continue macerating spongy clocks in the noisy lights of the coral reef.

Clear, amber body with a lightly brown, creamy head. Sourish aroma, clear Girardin touch with fruit, barnyard: very complex and well balanced. Moderately sour, lightly sweet flavour. Very nice and complex beer. Drinks very easily. Maybe tad too sweet.

Aroma: tart, cherry, funky
Taste: sweet, toasty, dust
This beer finished dry which was surprising with how sweet it was.
Pours a red color with no head. The taste is sweet, fruity with loads of rasberry flavors. Finshes slight sour and balanced. Light dry palate.
Även det en Lambic-Faro som hade mycket diskret doft, smaken var ganska söt med spår av tall och enbär. Kan inte mäta sig mot Straffe Winter.

750ml bottle shared with the crew 
Appearance: Clear amber with a medium off-white head and some lacing 
Aroma:Tart cherries 
Taste: Sweet sugars, tart fruit, woody and toasty  
Nice and smooth, easy drinking

Bottle.

Slightly hazy red/brownish with a small head. The aroma was rather fresh with light funk, sugar and something "green". The taste was rather sweet but not too sweet in my opinion. Not a complex beer but refreshing and descent.

750 ml bottle. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. Actually a darker copper color. A sweet aroma of brett, massive funky brett and some brown sugar. The flavor is a dead on Faro: sweet sugars, leather, wood, funky and light tart lambic elements, caramel, low carbonation. Very nice. Nothing unpleasant here and a Faro is nice to try from time to time. Very drinkable.
Brown/Amber colour. Smells chemical, paint from a spraycan and like a barbershop. Tastes sweet, but watery. Mouthfeel is quite thin and dry.

Bottle at Chris Os Pre-GBBF Shindig 2011. Amber color. Golden raisins, candy sugar, restrained sourness, raspberry and strawberry. Fairly drinklable but has only a faint of sourness (which is negative in this case).

30th July 2011>br>ChrisOs Donkey Dork Lord Pre-GBBF Tasting. Clear gold beer, tidy white head. Light dry palate. Sweetish faro flavours. Sweet vinegar, trace of white head. Little bit of fresh wood. Semi dry finish.

Nice mahogany body, no head. Barnyard aroma, sweaty, not too sour, some alcohol. Very mild taste with spices, cloves, coriander. Body is very thin. Aftertaste is quickly dissappearing, albeit quite pleasant.

Bottle:
Thanks to Benzai for sharing:
Small (off) white head turns into a lacing quick, on top of a clear dark orange colored beer.
Smells like a pilsner with some good malts and sweets added as well as some bacteria.
Taste is more Lambic-ish with sweets, malts and some dried hops.
Aftertaste of elderly dried hops with a touch of sour, sweets and wood.
Low carbo, tingly mouthfeel, medium body and a watery texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
750ml bottle (ChrisO Pre-GBBF2011 "Donkey Dork Lord" Shindig)
Sugary faro aroma. Pleasant tartness, but loads of sugar without being sticky. Simple and drinkable. Pretty good finesse, I doubt many people apart from Girardin or 3F could do something this sweet without making it slick. (And when I drank this, I didnt know it was Girardin, I only had the beer name.)
Clear dark orange / light amber color. Smell sweet with sour hints and barnyard. Aftertaste earth and ash. Taste sweet, artificial. Carbo and body ok.
Bottle at Chriso Pre GBBF shindig 2011.  Sweet faro.  Its a toffeeish thing with some ok sourness

Amber colour, small off-white head. Aroma is fruits, wood, caramel and some slight spicy notes. Flavour is sugary, wooden, mild sourness as well as some mildly tart wooden notes. Very nicely balanced and not overly sweet.

Bottle at chrisos Pre-GBBF Shindig 11. It pours orange-amber with a thin foamy white head . The nose is sweet caramel, pear, red apple and ice-tea. The taste is pear, tangy peach, sweet apple, ice-tea, sour lime and white sugar with some underlying sourness. Medium body and moderate carbonation. As Faros go this wasnt too bad.
Bottle at Chris Os pre GBBF shindig. Amber pour. Toffee and caramel aroma. Sweet flavour. Does exactly what a Faro normally does, no complaints here.

Bottle at ChrisOs Pre-GBBF Shindig 2011. Pours slightly hazy, ruby-gold with a small head. Sugary nose with light dough. Slightly tangy flavor, cheap sugar notes, light caramel. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish, plenty of spare sugar. Decent.
Bottle at Chrisos. Deep amber. Slight funk in nose, caramel, yogurt, fruit. Sweet, flavors of candi sugar, slight tartness and funk. Kind of boring.

A Mes rate. At Chris Os pre GBBF.Mid brown colour with a good off white head. Sweaty almost cheese-like aroma. Sweet and fruity in the mouth. Lots of candy sugar, rather harsh. Erm, yeah. The bottom line is, why would you drink this when wherever you buy it, its almost certain the Black Label would be available at the same time.
bottle at chriss ... copper ... light soft toffee fruit nose .. fizzy front ... light toffee ... light fruit ... some raspberry ... odd

UPDATED: APR 13, 2017 2014-05-30, bottle, tasting at Matts, 7-4-6-3-12=32Hazy amber color. Mild Lambic aroma, cellar, pepper, but somehow weird. Half-sweet, with some flavor of vegetables, very light Lambic, some sweetener.Weird.2010-11-27, bottle from Ølbaren, Copenhagen, 7-4-6-3-13=33Beautiful, bright and dark amber color; light carbonation produces a fast disappearing thin head. The aroma of Lambic is mellow, but nice, with soft tones of cellar. The flavor is simple, there is too little of the Lambic, some caramel, and a strange sweetener-like feeling.

Plörrig muffiger Antrunk und weiterer Geschmack, modrig, nicht säuerlich, überhaupt absolut nicht aromatisch. Disharmonisch, kein Arome ist irgendwie lecker, leicht malzig. Schrecklich!!! Danke an den Doppelbock für das Bier. 8/3/4/2/4/2
Bottle courtesy jtclockwork!  Nice reddish pour with a fuzzy off-white head that sticks.  Yeasty sour aroma with some caramel.  Surprisingly sour flavor with some funk and sweet sugars.  Nice!
Bottle shared with drowland. Pours clear red amber. Nose of grass, brown sugar and candi sugar. Taste of brown sugar, dry yeast and tart fruit.
Pretty disappointing.  Light caramel, medium light funk and a fairly simple, light sweet and sour flavor with a rather weird, bitter finish.

bottle-conditioned 750ml. early pour is bright and luminescent cedar/red apple in color with a medium-sized red-tinted head.  later pour is moderately murky, and the yeast helps open things up (less red apple skin and candy sugar, more funk). exceptionally rich nose, a combination of mild-to-moderate farmhouse/goat/dusty character, mild oak, and semi-sweet brown sugar/maple syrup - it smells like the flour, breads, meats, equipment and walls of a rustic kitchen.  the balance of acid and sugar is remarkable: its quenching and far too easily quaffable, with the acid attacking the underside of the tongue while the candy sugar tempers the mild egg/sulphur note. the sweetness is not excessive, the acidity is not overdone, its pleasant and enjoyable in all aspects.   this is belgian table beer, plain and simple, and its exceptionally nuanced and subtly decadent. thirst-quenching, pairs perfectly with a mixture of cheese and meats (good fats to play with the acid), and I could drink this with every meal.  the best bottled faro in existence.
Dark brown and murky with minimal head.  Malt and sourness on the aroma with a bit of staleness.  Sweet candied fruit flavor with some sourness.

(bottle, 75cl) Almost clear, amber colour with a big but collapsing off-white foamy head. Slightly sweet malty aroma with mouldy and sweaty hoppy notes, accompanied by a rather restrained fruity touch and a mildly spicy note. Moderately sweet and slightly sour flavour, light to medium bodied with a calm carbonation. Light Lambic-character with fruity notes;  sweet and slightly bitter-tart and spicy finish with an ascorbic tartness in the aftertaste. Not my thing. 29.VI.10

Many thanks to BDR!  Murky copper color with a thin head.  Slight dusty malt aroma and hints of sourness.  Very sugary flavor, both candi sugar and some kind of candied fruit.  More sour than tart.  Light hoppiness towards the end (well, hoppy for a lambic).

2010 on the cork; sampled July 2010
A soft pour produces a two-finger thick, lightly tan tinged head.  The beer is a dark, burnt amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, brown honey color when held up to the light.  The aroma smells like caramelized fruit, a mix of pear and apple really, as well as a touch of sweet-tea notes, some anchoring tartness as well as some dark grain cracker like notes in the finish if you really dig around for a while.  A touch of urea ties in the Lambic origin as do some faint musty and even mushroom like earthy notes.  It almost seems to have a sugary smokiness to it at times, though this is quite fleeting.

Because fairly warm the beer is not overwhelmingly sweet; it does have a sweetness though, and one that lingers in the finish with a fruity, caramelized candi sugar note.  Lightly tart up front and it has a zippy carbonation that makes it a bit carbonic, all of these help to balance the candi-sugar flavors.  Fruity flavors of candied pears, perhaps a touch of sweetened lemon (more like crystal light than actual lemons though) and perhaps a tart berry like flavor are all accentuated by the sweetness.

Not a bad Faro, it could use some more funkiness, as it is completely devoid of this character in the flavor.  The sweetness is not too overwhelming here and I could almost see myself drinking this again, though it doesnt hold a candle to the 3 Fonteinen Faro.

Bottle: Almost clear, quite stable loose off-white head, nearly reddish-amber coloured; delicate cellary-mouldy nose with a distinctive sweetish-fruity background; moderate sweet-sourish flavour, light to medium bodied, soft; slightly increasing hoppiness in the caramelly-fruity finish, accompanied by faint cellary aromas. O.K.....

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Some yeasty notes. Moderate sweet and bitter flavor. Only slightly sour. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
caramel, brown sugar,golden, clear, tan foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish.
75 cl bottle. Amber with diminishing off-white head. Flavour is sour, fruit and caramel.
Lighjt amber and clear. Has a white head. Aroma is spicy, pepper, light fruit, nice. Flavor is heavy sweet. A bit astringent. Syrupy texture. Soft carbonation.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with a small white head and a fair lacing. Nice acidic aroma and taste sugary notes. A good faro.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are brett yeast, malt, caramel, molasses and vinegar.

Corked bottle. Brown color. Caramel, leather and bitter walnuts in the aroma. Caramelly sweet with a light sourness. Cola flavor with some vegetable notes. leather and citrus in the aftertaste. Interesting beer.

Bottled. Deep amber coloured. quite clear. Small off white head. Aroma of fruits, wood, light earth, sweetness, and light sourness. Flavour of wood, light leather, sweetness, grape and some earth. Medium bodied. Dry light sour end with a tad of sweetness. By far not the best faro Ive tried, but definately drinkable and pleasant.

Nice faro - much better than the green one from the same brewery. Sweet and sour with no hint of the flat, dull elements that can be found in other faros (fari?). Spring and fall in one little bottle.

Bottle. Astonishingly high and creamy off-white lasting head. Clear brown body. Mild and almost sweet grapefruit horse blanket straw dry and dusty aroma. Relatively sweet caramel sour berries lemon flavor with low carbonation and a short aftertaste.

Bottle 750ml. @ home.Clear medium red amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, fruity - berry, light barnyard, sour, vanilla ? strawberry ? Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light moderate acidic with a long to average duration, and a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091016]

Bottle, 75cl corked. A clear, almost copper-colored beer topped by a small beige head. Dark sugar, cellar, spiced notes and some tropical fruits in the aroma. The flavor is sweet and grainy, cellarish with some citrus. Nice bitterness in the end. Dry, medium-bodied. An easy drinkable beer, but too weak all the way. 090828
Amber with an off white head. Caramel in aroma along with brown sugar and spices. Flavour is sweet with carame, brown sugar and fruit.
Bottle . Dark golden colour with a white head. Flavour is sweet, sour, sugar, fruit, candis sugar, caramel, yeast. Nice beer.

Bottle from Kempisch Bierfestival. Pours copper with a small offwhite head. Lemony lambik aroma as well as caramel. Sweetened and slightly spiced lemony lambik. Semi-dry. When the startingpoint is Girardin lambik, you can never go completely wrong.

Bottle from Dranken Geers, Oostakker, Gent, Belgium, consumed 19-11-09   Pours rusty red with a couple of white bubbly islands floatoing on the top, otherwise the carbonation is a little more muted than I expected. Taste is sweet which totally tempers the underlying sourness, sort of sacchriney sweet at times tasting just a little artificial. Bit soad like as well, quite fruity and tangy, soft in mouth but altogether this is a quite safe beer, fine and in fact quite reasonable but nothing exciting.  A6 A4 F6 P3 Ov12  3.1

Slighly hazy yellowish orange color with small red hues. A rather big off-white head that actually stays around for quite a while (not very common when it comes to lambics) and leaves nice lacings.

The smell is refreshing and pleasant with quite a lot of sweet fruit aromas (tangerines and peaches) that reside on and suppress some rustic aromas of hay, yeast and malts. Hints of fudge and caramel. The classic lambic character in this one is light and mellow, but its noticeable.

The taste is mild and easy-going. The malty backbone is quite prominent with plenty of flavors of fudge and caramel. Some semi-sweet fruit aromas. Hints of grass, yeast and hay, and perhaps a minimal note of oak barrel. The finish has a mild lemony tartness to it and this helps to balance the otherwise rather sweet taste. The finish is short and one-sided with a light maltiness and some fruit.

Moderate body. Slightly stickier than expected and the finish lacks the dryness of most lambics.

Im not sure about this one. Its tasty and easy to drink, but its a bit restrained and uninteresting. Its a bit on the sweet side and has quite an unusual composition of flavors (lots of malts and caramel) considering that its a lambic. I would have liked more character and en edgier profile with less sweetness.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)
Bottle. Pours a copper color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish fruity caramel and sugary aroma. Fruity sugary caramel flavor. Has a sweetish fruity sugary spicy finish.

75cL bottle. Pours translucent amber, capped with a medium sized ivory head. Aroma is mildly tart, with notes of tropical fruit, citrus, caramel, and sugar. Flavor is relatively sweet, with caramel, dark fruit, candi sugar, and mild herbal notes. Sweetness lingers, and gradually gives way to some astringent character.

Bottle.Pours clear brownish with a dissipating white head.Nice cellar and caramel aroma.Very sweet with an moderate sourness.Some cellar ,funk ,oak and fruitiness in the flavor too.Nice, but a little on the sweet side.
red, brown, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, soft carbonation, bread,
amber coloured body with a white head a spicy sour fruity aroma a soury fruity sweet taste with a soury bitter finish
Clear reddish coloured beer with medium white head. Sour aroma. bit fruity. Full sweet palate. Finish is soft sour ending dry.

Bottle, bought @ Vinens Verden, Odense.
Pours clear copper with a small, frothy, off-white head. Aroma has red apples, subdued caramel and a light berry touch. Medium prickly carbonation, light dryish mouthfeel. Flavour has soft tartness as its background, light caramel, sweet sugar. A touch of spiciness as well. As weird as faro always is.
Mild nose with hints of sour cream, earthlyness, grass. A bit of sour sweetness in the flavor with vaint notes of wood and fruit. Mild, drinkable and rather forgetable too. Back on 100% faros :)

Bottle, 75 cl.  Find @ Hopduvel.
Almost clear amber color, with a off-white head. 
Aroma sweet, fruits, caramel. 
Medium body.
Taste sweet, caramel, fruit, and a light bitterness in the finish. Sweet for a Girardin beer.

Bottle thanks to Andreasen11. 
Pours an amber colour with a dense beige head. 
The aroma is sweet with notes of malt, fruit, wood and brettanomyces. 
Flavour is also sweet with notes of rock candy, fruit and a malty hint. 
Its somewhat watery but with a pleasant after taste.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2009 Bottle. Courtesy of Andreasen11. Amber body with a medium off white head. Aroma is caramel, light sour cherries and fruit. Flavour is light citric, sweet malt and fruit. Medium bodied.

Botella grande given by Pinball, thanks! Deep clear amber colour, fair medium head. Brett, dark fruity and brown sugar aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour is sweet with brett, dark fruits, caramel, some wood and a pleasant soft bitterness.
Very sparkly orange Faro. Taste is pleasant but not sofisticated at all. Nice for a simple refreshing drink.

amber of color with a small off white head. An aroma of sweets and caramel, weak sour, metallic and berries. A flavor with sugar, candy, metallic, bitter and weak sour notes. A finish with grass and bitter notes.
Bottle. Amber coloured with a lacing off white head. Sweet and sugared aroma with notes of caramel, dark fruit and a bit dusty. Fruity sweet flavour with caramel, wood and sour notes.

From Barley Wine, Copenhagen, DK.
Bottled, 200609.
Brown with off-white head. Aroma of cane sugar and hay. Flavor is sugar sweet with a tone of vineous dryness, fruit and wood

(75cl bottle, JorisPPattyn kindly shared)  Pours a clear amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of candi sugar, caramel, and fruity notes.  Flavor of candi sugar, fruit, and light grassiness with mild bitterness in the finish.  Very sweet around.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2012 Amber with a small white head. Aroma of bready malt, vineous dried fruits and brown sugar. Sweet fruity flavour, caramel and wood, and a little tartness that makes it very drinkable. 6-3-7-3-13 = 3.2
Odense Catching Up on Stuff Left in the Cellar Event July 2012. 2010 vintage. Developed into something much funkier and a bit tart. Who knew that a faro needed time to develop! Great aroma, still a sweet and not-quite-right flavour
oro buona schiuma media persitenza note dolciastre caramello un po di spezia in bocca tendente al dolce lieve acidità un po di legno un faro speziato sembra

Small white rim over orange-amber beer, clear. Wood, brown candi sugar, fruity, like preserved fruit. Very Faro-like, with wood, again lots of candi sugar. Finish being faintly sourish, dried apricot, and a bit spicy. Sticky, well)bodied, syrupy. Why dont they just call this faro - thats what it is. Way too sweet, too, and a bit of spices wont change a d*mn.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a clear amber golden with a small, rough, off-white head. Lightly tart aroma with notes of fruit and caramel. Medium body, lightly tart, lightly fruity and lightly sulphurous. Notes of brown sugar. Very discreet bitterness. Mostly this reminds me of a Faro. An easy and pleasant drink. 300409

75cl bottle @ VinensVerden, Odense. POurs a cloudy amber with a white foam and lacings. Nose is sweet and matured. Caramel, toffee, cherries and dark fruits. Taste is a bit cloying with hints of almond & corn. Medium bodied. Very sweet. Would have loved a more tart cherry feel.
75 cl, beautiful amber colour with white head. Bit sweet but you can still taste the lambic in it. Good balance between sour and sweet. Soft beer with a nice after taste and certainly easy to drink.

Bottle at yespr.
Clear orange coloured with a small off white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma of vinegar and butterscotsch.
Fruity flavour of grain with notes of caramel and vinegar.
Fruity finish.
Clear amber with a medium off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with malty and caramel notes. Sweet flavour with malty and fruity notes. Somewhat watery. Finished sweet.

75cl bottle.
clear orange, small white head.
slightly sour aroma, very nice. mildly spicy beligan way.
flavor is citrussy,  sweet. well balanced, almost a little cider like.

Bottled. A slightly hazy dark amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet and acidic with notes candy sugar. The aroma is sweet with just a hint of acidity and notes of of candy sugar and a bit of metal, and some artificial sweetener. Is the a Faro? Thanks yespr for sharing.

75 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Mild fruity and yeasty aroma. MIld citric and fruity flavoured. Vague acetone note and potential for development. Mild citric and fruity flavoured finish.
Bottle at ØLbaren - thanks. Clear pink - white head. High sweetness, high sparkling, minerals, artificial, light raspberries. Thin body and finish. Boring.
75cl, new exclusive brew Anno 2009, sweet brew blended with lambic, from De Hopduvel Gent, not complex brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, nice brew
